data.title: Understanding Structured Settlements: A Complete Guide
data.meta_description: Structured settlements allow injury victims to be paid over time instead of as a lump sum. Discover how they work and why they are a secure financial solution.
data.text:
A structured settlement is a financial arrangement where the injured party agrees to resolve their damage claim by receiving part or all of the settlement in the form of periodic payments on an agreed schedule, rather than as a lump sum. The payment schedule can be structured in many ways to meet the needs of the injured party, including payments for life, over a set number of years, or even delayed until the claimant reaches a certain age. This option is often preferred as it provides long-term financial security to the claimant, especially if they have sustained debilitating injuries that would affect their ability to work.

When are Structured Settlements Typically Used?

Structured settlements are typically used in personal injury cases where the claimant has suffered severe injuries that require long-term or lifetime medical care. These include incidents like severe car accidents, medical malpractice, or workplace injuries.

The structured settlement helps cover ongoing medical costs, living expenses, and any other financial needs that arise due to the injury. Moreover, structured settlements can also be used in cases involving minors to ensure financial stability once they come of age, or in wrongful death cases to provide ongoing income support for the decedent’s dependents. The goal is to establish a reliable income stream for the claimant to maintain their quality of life and facilitate needs arising from the injury.

What are the Payment Options for Structured Settlements?

Structured settlements offer various payment options to cater to the unique needs of the claimant. Here are some of the common structured settlement payment options:

Lump-Sum Distributions: A portion of the settlement is paid out as a lump sum immediately upon settlement, with the remainder paid out over time.

Deferred Payments: Payments start after a certain period, allowing the claimant time to adjust before handling the additional income.

Life-Contingent Payments: Payments are made for as long as the claimant lives.

Periodic Lump Sums: Certain amounts are paid out at regular intervals (e.g., every five years) in addition to regular payments.

Increasing or Decreasing Payments: Payments increase or decrease over time to account for expected changes in the claimant’s living expenses.

Payments for Life with Certain Period: Payments are made for the claimant’s life but if they die early, the payments continue to a beneficiary for a certain period.

Joint and Survivor Annuity: Payments continue for the life of the claimant and then for the life of their survivor.

It’s essential to choose the right option depending on your financial goals and life circumstances. Therefore, consulting with your injury attorney and a financial advisor is highly recommended.

Advantages of Structured Settlements

Structured settlements offer several advantages in personal injury cases:

Guaranteed Income: Structured settlements provide a steady and reliable stream of income over a specified period. This helps the claimant manage their financial needs effectively.

Tax Benefits: The income received through a structured settlement is generally tax-free, providing a significant financial advantage over lump-sum settlements.

Customizable: The payment schedule can be customized according to the claimant’s needs, taking into account future expenses and cost-of-living adjustments.

Protection Against Poor Money Management: As the money is paid out over time, it reduces the risk of poor financial management or impulse spending, which can occur with a large lump-sum payment.

No Risk of Investment: Unlike a lump-sum payment, which may be subject to the volatility of financial markets if invested, structured settlements offer a safe and secure financial plan.

Remember, it’s essential to consult with a financial advisor and your attorney to understand the full implications of settling a personal injury claim with a structured settlement.

What are the Tax Benefits of Using a Structured Settlement?

The tax benefits of using a structured settlement are significant and codified in the United States tax law. According to the Periodic Payment Settlement Act of 1982, the full amount of the structured settlement payments is tax-free to the recipient. This legislation made it clear that an injured party would not be liable for any taxes on the settlement, regardless of how the payments were structured.

Furthermore, Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section 104(a)(2) clarifies that the entire amount of a personal physical injury settlement is exempt from taxation, whether it is received as a lump sum or as structured settlement payments. This tax exclusion applies to the interest earned on the settlement, which otherwise would be taxable if the money were invested.

Hence, these tax laws provide a significant financial advantage to structured settlements, helping injured parties keep the full sum of their compensation, and ensuring they have a reliable, tax-free income stream to support their long-term recovery and quality of life. Remember, it’s always crucial to consult with a tax advisor or attorney to understand the full tax implications of a structured settlement in your personal circumstances.

Disadvantages of Structured Settlements

Despite the considerable benefits, structured settlements also have some potential disadvantages:

Lack of Flexibility: Once a structured settlement is set up, it can be challenging to change the payment terms. This could pose a problem if the claimant’s financial situation changes and they require more funds than their scheduled payments provide.

Inflation Risk: The value of fixed payments can decrease over time due to inflation, especially in long-term settlements. Even though some plans account for cost-of-living adjustments, these may not always keep pace with actual inflation rates.

Access to Lump-Sum Money: Structured settlements are designed to provide regular income, which means the claimant won’t have a significant amount of money available in case of an emergency or to cover large, unforeseen expenses.

Potential of Insurer’s Insolvency: There is always a small risk that the insurance company responsible for paying the structured settlement might become insolvent in the future, which could potentially affect the payout.

Missed Investment Opportunities: With a lump sum payment, the claimant could invest the money, potentially earning more over time than the structured settlement would provide.

It’s crucial to weigh these disadvantages against the advantages when considering a structured settlement. Each personal injury case is unique, and the injured party should consult with their attorney and financial advisor to determine the best course of action.

Example of a Structured Settlement for a Personal Injury Claim

Consider a scenario where a person, let’s call him John, has suffered a severe personal injury due to a workplace accident. After a court case, it is determined that John is to receive a total of $1.5 million in compensation. Instead of taking a lump-sum payment, John decides to opt for a structured settlement. His arrangement could look something like this:

Immediate Cash: John receives an immediate cash payment of $300,000. This money helps to cover immediate medical bills, repay debts, and provide a financial cushion for immediate living expenses.

Deferred Payments: The remaining $1.2 million is invested in an annuity that will provide him with regular payments over a specified period. John chooses to receive $5,000 per month for the next 20 years, amounting to $60,000 per year and a total of $1.2 million over the agreed period.

Inflation Adjustment: John’s structured settlement also includes an adjustment for inflation, ensuring that the purchasing power of his monthly payments does not decrease over time.

This example illustrates how a structured settlement can provide a steady income stream over a long period and the flexibility to meet immediate financial needs. It also highlights the tax benefits that come with structured settlements, as John’s regular payments are not taxed. However, it’s critical to remember that everyone’s situation is unique and this is just one of many possible structured settlement examples. Always consult with a financial advisor or attorney to understand the full implications of settling a personal injury claim with a structured settlement.

Is a Structured Settlement Right for You?

Deciding whether a structured settlement is the right choice for you depends on numerous factors, primarily your financial needs, future plans, and ability to manage large sums of money. If you anticipate significant future expenses, such as ongoing medical costs or educational fees, a structured settlement can provide a reliable, continuous income stream to meet these needs.

Furthermore, if managing a lump sum is not your forte, the gradual payout of a structured settlement can protect you from poor financial decisions or impulse spending. However, if you prefer to have control over a large sum and are confident in your investment skills, a lump sum may be more suitable.
